[[Image:Patrick French Plane.jpg|right|thumb|Patrick French]] '''Patrick French''' (born 1966) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] writer and [[historian]], based in [[London]]. He was educated at the [[University of Edinburgh]] where he studied [[English literature|English]] and [[American literature]].<ref>[http://catdir.loc.gov/catdir/bios/random054/2002043432.html Library of Congress entry]</ref>
French is the author of several books including : ''Younghusband: The Last Great Imperial Adventurer'' (1994), a biography of [[Francis Younghusband]], ''[[The World Is What It Is]]'' (2008), an authorized biography of [[Nobel Prize|Nobel]] Laureate [[V.S Naipaul]] which won the [[National Book Critics Circle Award]] in the [[United States of America]].<ref>[http://www.randomhouse.com/author/results.pperl?authorid=52606 Author biography on Random House website]</ref>, and ''India: A Portrait. An intimate biography of 1.2 billion people.''(2010)
During the [[1992 general election (UK)|1992 general election]], French was a [[Green Party of England and Wales|Green Party]] candidate for [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]]. He has sat on the executive committee of the Tibet Support Group UK, and was a founding member of the inter-governmental [[India]]-[[UK]] Round Table.<ref>[http://www.biblio.com/author_biographies/2836691/Patrick_French.html Author Profile]</ref>
== Books and Awards ==
At the age of 25, French set off on a trail across [[Central Asia]] to retrace the steps of [[British people|British]] explorer [[Francis Younghusband]]. This resulted in the publication of his first book, ''Younghusband: The Last Great Imperial Adventurer'' in 1994.<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/15/books/books-of-the-times-an-impulsive-imperial-soldier-who-turned-guru.html An Impulsive Imperial Soldier Who Turned Guru] The New York Times. November 15, 1995.</ref> The book went on to win both the [[Somerset Maugham Award]]<ref>[http://www.societyofauthors.org/prizes-grants-and-awards/prizes-for-fiction-and-non-fiction/the_somerset_maugham_awards/somerset_maugham_past_winners.html List of Past Winners of the Somerset Maugham Award]</ref> and the [[Royal Society of Literature]]âs W.H. Heinemann Prize.
Frenchâs next book, ''Liberty or Death â Indiaâs Journey to Independence and Division'' was published in 1997 and earned the author accolades and brickbats in equal parts. Described in the Indian media as presenting a ârevisionist viewâ of [[Mahatma Gandhi]] and [[Mohammad Ali Jinnah]]âs role in the [[Indian Independence movement]],<ref>[http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?203970 Gandhi was a wily Politician, Jinnah remained a secularist till Death] Outlook Magazine. August 6, 1997</ref> there were a few calls to ban the book in [[India]]. On the other hand, [[Philip Ziegler]] hailed it as âa remarkable achievement,â<ref>[http://www.amazon.com/dp/0006550452 Reviews and Reader Reviews on Amazon]</ref> and Khushwant Singh described the author as âa first rate historian and storyteller.â The book sold heavily due to the controversy and French was awarded the [[London Sunday Times]] Young Author of the Year award for the book.<ref>[http://www.societyofauthors.org/prizes-grants-and-awards/prizes-for-fiction-and-non-fiction/the_sunday_times_young_writer/sunday_times_past_winners.html List of Past Winners of the Sunday Times Young Author award]</ref>
Published in 2003, ''Tibet, Tibet: A Personal History Of A Lost Land'' was Frenchâs third book. According to the authorâs own accounts, his interest in [[Tibet]] was triggered by a meeting he had with the [[Dalai Lama]] when he was 16. The book though emerged out of âa gradual nervousness that the western idea of Tibet, particularly the views of Tibet campaigners, was becoming too detached from the reality of what Tibet was like. So I did a long journey through Tibet in 1999.â<ref>[http://www.outlookindia.com/fullprint.asp?choice=1&fodname=20030310&fname=french&sid=1 Interview: Nandini Lal on Patrick French] Outlook Magazine. March 10, 2003.</ref> [[The Independent]] described the book as âintelligent as well as passionate in its approach.â<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/reviews/tibet-tibet-a-personal-history-of-a-lost-land-by-patrick-french-593811.html Book Review: Tibet, Tibet, A Personal History Of A Lost Land] The Independent. April 12, 2003.</ref> [[Pico Iyer]] in [[The Los Angeles Times]] book review described French as a "scrupulous and disciplined writer" who "has a decided gift for inspired and heartfelt research and a knack for coming upon overlooked details that are worth several volumes of analysis."<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2003/oct/19/books/bk-iyer19 Himalayan Descent] The Los Angeles Times. October 19, 2003</ref>
''[[The World Is What It Is]]'', an authorized biography of [[Nobel Prize|Nobel]] prize winning author [[V.S Naipaul]] was published in 2008. In the ''[[New York Review of Books]]'', [[Ian Buruma]] conferred French as the inventor of a new genre, âthe confessional biography.â<ref>[http://www.nybooks.com/articles/22062 The Lessons of the Master] The New York Review of Books. November 20, 2008.</ref> The book was selected by the editors of ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]'' as one of the â10 Best books of 2008.â<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/14/books/review/10Best-t.html?_r=2 The ten best books of 2008] The New York Times. December 3, 2008.</ref> In 2008, ''[[The World Is What It Is]]'' was awarded the [[National Book Critics Circle Award]]<ref>[http://bookcritics.org/awards Winners of the National Book Critics Circle Award]</ref> in America, and was also short listed for the [[Samuel Johnson]] Prize.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbcfour/books/features/samueljohnson/shortlist.shtml List of Winners of the Samuel Johnson Prize]</ref> French was also awarded the [[Hawthornden Prize]] in 2009 for the book.<ref>[http://www.panmacmillan.com/News/displayPage.asp?PageTitle=Patrick%20French%20awarded%20literary%20prize Patrick French awarded Literary prize]</ref>
In 2010, Patrick released his book 'India: A Portrait'. He calls it 'an intimate biography of 1.2 billion people'. The book is a narrative of the social and economic revolutions that are transforming India. As part of the book release, he has also started an India focused website called The India Site.<ref>http://www.theindiasite.com/india-a-portrait/</ref>
== Personal Life ==
He is married to Meru Gokhale, currently an Editor at [[Penguin Group]] in the UK, and the daughter of author and publisher [[Namita Gokhale]]. This is his second marriage.
==Views==
In 2003, French was offered the [[Order of the British Empire]] (OBE).<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/3158852.stm Naipaul biographer refuses OBE]</ref>
